channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: E.U. Blames Belarus for Migrant Crisis at Poland Border
item.description: Poland has massed troops at the border, the European Union’s eastern frontier, to keep migrants camped there from crossing into the country.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Monika Pronczuk and Anatol Magdziarz
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: India Risks Covid-19 Complacency After Its Vaccine Campaign
item.description: The success represents a major victory for Narendra Modi’s government, but a recent slowdown in new vaccinations has sparked worries.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A health worker inoculating a man at a health center in the Uttar Pradesh state in India in June.

item.title: France Will Require Booster Shot for Those 65 and Older
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron, in a televised speech, said that older people will now have to get the shots to remain eligible for a vaccine passport.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron last month in Paris.

item.title: Afghan Pilots Who Escaped Taliban Are Flown Out of Tajikistan
item.description: More than 140 Afghan Air Force pilots and crew members were evacuated to the United Arab Emirates three months after flying into Tajikistan to escape the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan Air Force ground crew members servicing a military plane in Kabul in 2018.

item.title: Ethiopia Seizes 16 UN Workers Amid Efforts to Halt Tigray War
item.description: The detentions aggravated the already tense relations between the United Nations and the Ethiopian government over war and famine in the country’s northern Tigray region.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: A military parade in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, on Sunday.

item.title: Africa's Leaders Say Rich Countries Need to Quit Oil and Gas First
item.description: As negotiators at the Glasgow climate talks try to agree on greenhouse gas cuts, African leaders say poorer countries can’t be expected to remake their systems as quickly as wealthy ones.
item.dc:creator: Shola Lawal
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: A new solar panel in Lagos, Nigeria, last year. “It’s the bigger emitters that should have the responsibility to cut,” one analyst said of fossil fuels. “We should be sensitive to history.”

item.title: Brexit Brain Drain Delivers Financial Boon to Estonia
item.description: The former Soviet satellite state is welcoming British companies looking to escape the tangle of regulations and financial obstacles of doing business in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: A view of Tallinn, the Estonian capital. Several thousand British companies have registered in the country, seeking access to a wider European market.

item.title: Paytm's Parent Company, One97 Communications, Goes Public
item.description: One97 Communications, the app’s parent company, has drawn interest from institutional investors as online shopping in India expands.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall
item.media:description: A billboard in Mumbai, India, promoting Paytm, a cellphone-based digital payments platform.

item.title: U.S. Travel Ban Ends, and Europeans Head Overseas Again
item.description: Europeans were kept apart from family and friends as the ban dragged on long after E.U. leaders had opened their borders.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Charles de Gaulle airport outside Paris in September.

item.title: E.U. Blames Belarus for Migrant Crisis at Poland Border
item.description: Poland has massed troops at the border, the European Union’s eastern frontier, to keep migrants camped there from crossing into the country.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Monika Pronczuk and Anatol Magdziarz
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: ‘America Is Back’ Pelosi Says at Glasgow Climate Talks
item.description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez was among a group of Democratic lawmakers who traveled with Ms. Pelosi to barnstorm the COP26 climate summit.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Nancy Pelosi, Speaker of the United States House of Representatives, addresses the audience during Gender Day at the COP26 UN Climate Summit in Glasgow, Britain, on Tuesday.

item.title: Can Glasgow Deliver on a Global Climate Deal?
item.description: Negotiators from about 200 countries are entering Week 2 of climate talks trying to resolve big issues around money, transparency and timelines.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Kieran Dodds for The New York Times
item.media:description: A meeting of the Coalition of Finance Ministers for Climate Action in Glasgow last week.

item.title: Military Can’t Find ISIS Safe House That Prompted Kabul Drone Strike
item.description: The Pentagon’s latest admission illustrates the botched intelligence behind the strike that mistakenly killed 10 civilians in August.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times

item.title: Justice Dept. Brings New Charges in Ransomware Attacks
item.description: The department said it had charged a Russian national in one attack and recovered $6.1 million in ransom. It also arrested a Ukrainian man for another attack.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner and Nicole Perlroth
item.media:description: Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director, left, and Attorney General Merrick B. Garland at the Justice Department on Monday. The department has recently escalated its fight against cyber crime.

item.title: Barack Obama Calls for 'Ongoing Activism' In COP26 Speech
item.description: The former president, who helped seal the Paris climate accord, spoke at COP26 in Glasgow.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Andrew Milligan/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Former President Barack Obama, center, at the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow on Monday.

item.title: In Romania, Hard-Hit by Covid, Doctors Fight Vaccine Refusal
item.description: An anti-vaccine clarion call by leading religious figures, echoed by prominent politicians and social media, helps explain why Romania now has the world’s highest Covid death rate.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Cristian Movila for The New York Times
item.media:description: The emergency unit of Bucharest University Hospital. Short of beds, the hospital erected a big treatment tent in the parking lot and turned the lobby into a new Covid ward.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Troops at the Poland-Belarus border.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Hundreds of people camped at the Belarus-Poland border in frigid weather seeking to enter Poland.

item.title: U.S. Holocaust Museum Says China ‘May Be Committing Genocide’ Against Uyghurs
item.description: Its report found that the government’s attacks against the group of Muslims in Xinjiang had escalated and most likely included “forced sterilization, sexual violence, enslavement, torture, and forcible transfer.”
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Simon-Skjodt Center for the Prevention of Genocide
item.media:description: Members of a Uyghur family prayed at the grave of a loved one at a cemetery in Xinjiang in 2016.

item.title: Malala Yousafzai Is Married in England
item.description: Ms. Yousafzai, a Pakistani activist and the youngest-ever recipient of a Nobel Peace Prize, married her partner at a small ceremony in Birmingham, England, she said on Twitter.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:description: Malala Yousafzai married Asser Malik, a manager for the Pakistan Cricket Board, at a small ceremony in Birmingham, England.

item.title: Pakistan Reaches Cease-Fire With Resurgent Taliban Militants
item.description: The Pakistani government said it would offer amnesty for insurgents who are willing to disarm.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: A military outpost in Khyber District, Pakistan, in August.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: India’s Covid turnaround has blind spots.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A healthcare worker administers a dose of the coronavirus vaccine in Ahmedabad, India, in June.

item.title: Canada Approves Pfizer Boosters for Adults
item.description: Some provinces have already started to offer booster shots to higher-risk populations. Tuesday’s announcement standardizes eligibility criteria nationwide.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: A health care worker administers the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine at a pop-up clinic in Toronto this year.

item.title: Macron announces a new vaccine rule for people 65 or older in France.
item.description: Though the country has a high vaccination rate, new coronavirus cases and hospital admissions have been increasing in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Red Cross volunteers helping a man activate his pass on the TousAntiCovid contact-tracing application in Le Bourget, France.

item.title: Dutch government rejects hundreds of millions of pieces of protective gear.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Sem Van Der Wal/ANP/AFP via Getty Images
item.media:description: A health worker performing a coronavirus test in Utrecht. The Netherlands has reported almost 77,000 cases over the past week.

item.title: England Will Require N.H.S. Workers to Be Vaccinated by April
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle

item.title: New Zealand’s Sea Lions Are Back, and Crashing Golf Courses and Soccer Matches
item.description: After their populations were decimated by hunters, New Zealand’s sea lions are returning to the coasts — sometimes surprising locals by turning up in unexpected places.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Graham-McLay

item.title: India Hospital Fire Leaves at Least 4 Infants Dead
item.description: The blaze, in a hospital in central India on Monday night, was the latest in a series of deadly fires at health care centers in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: A man carried a child out of the Kamla Nehru Hospital in Bhopal, India, on Monday after a deadly fire engulfed the newborn care unit.

item.title: A Trash Can From Myrtle Beach Washed Up in Ireland
item.description: “It reminded me straight away of maybe like a message in a bottle type scenario,” said Keith McGreal, who discovered the bin on Sunday afternoon while strolling on a beach with his family.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy and Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Mr. McGreal and his children spotted a blue object in the distance and decided to race toward it.

item.title: Scientists confront a new source of vaccine misinformation: Aaron Rodgers.
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson and Emily Anthes
item.media:description: Aaron Rodgers of the Green Bay Packers watching action from the sideline during a game against the Arizona Cardinals last month in Glendale, Ariz.

item.title: In Hong Kong, a mandatory smartphone app draws pushback and mockery.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: A woman scanning the government’s contact tracing QR code for the “LeaveHomeSafe” mobile app before entering a Hong Kong market last week.

item.title: What Moves Swing Voters
item.description: A creative new poll tries to understand.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Ahmed Gaber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election Day in New York City.

item.title: U.S. Urges Release of Chinese Citizen Journalist Who Documented Covid
item.description: Zhang Zhan, who was imprisoned after exposing the failures of the government’s initial response to the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan, is near death, friends and family say.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Zhang Zhan in a park during a visit to Wuhan, China, last year.

item.title: Protest outside New Zealand’s Parliament assails sweeping new Covid mandates.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A demonstration to demand an end to Covid-19 restrictions and mandatory vaccination in Wellington, New Zealand, on Tuesday.

item.title: Singapore to End Free Covid Treatment for Those 'Unvaccinated by Choice'
item.description: The change, which takes effect on Dec. 8, comes as the number of severe cases has stabilized but remains high, the Health Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Taking rapid antigen tests in September in Singapore, where severe Covid cases are testing the city’s hospitals.

item.title: How a 55-Year-Old California Teacher Became a Bollywood Actor
item.description: Richard Klein left behind his life as a Hebrew day school teacher in California and became an actor in Mumbai, often playing a “mean British officer.”
item.dc:creator: Sheila Yasmin Marikar
item.media:credit: Prarthna Singh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Richard Klein rehearses in his apartment in the Mumbai suburb of Bandra. Behind him is his sidekick, an orange rescue cat named Mr. Bill.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Vaccine refusal in Romania.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Cristian Movila for The New York Times
item.media:description: The emergency unit of Bucharest University Hospital.

item.title: U.S. Allows Vaccinated Foreign Travelers to Enter
item.description: On Monday, after more than 18 months, restrictions that kept families separated and cost the global travel industry hundreds of billions of dollars were lifted.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu, Heather Murphy and Concepción de León
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Débora and Sergio Vitorini flew from São Paulo, Brazil, to see their daughter Natalia and her weeks-old son. They had not been able to see her during the pregnancy.

item.title: More Than 40 Nations Pledge to Cut Emissions From Their Health Industries
item.description: The plans, while short on specifics, represent a notable step toward cutting greenhouse gas emissions from hospitals and the health care industry, a sizable emitter globally.
item.dc:creator: Winston Choi-Schagrin
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Isadora Kosofsky for the New York Times
item.media:description: The health care industry currently accounts for almost five percent of global greenhouse gas emissions.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Emotional reunions at U.S. airports.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Alex Ingram for The New York Times
item.media:description: Virgin Airways employees at Heathrow airport in London welcomed travelers heading to the United States on Monday.

item.title: Expensive Virus Test Still Hinders Canadian Travel to U.S.
item.description: Canada requires travelers to present the results of an expensive coronavirus test to enter, deterring short hops across the border.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Hallie Golden
item.media:description: A coronavirus testing site near the Rainbow Bridge in Niagara Falls, N.Y.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius, Olympic Runner Convicted of Murder, Is Up for Parole
item.description: The double-amputee sprinter has served half his sentence for killing his girlfriend. His victim’s parents were said to be “shocked” at the prospect of his release.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius leaving a sentencing hearing in 2016.

item.title: French Catholic Church Will Sell Assets to Compensate Abuse Victims
item.description: The measure was one of several measures announced by French bishops, one month after a landmark report on sexual abuse by clergy members in France.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: “We will ensure that no one is left behind,” Éric de Moulins-Beaufort, the archbishop of Reims and the president of the Bishops’ Conference of France, told reporters in Lourdes, France, on Monday.

item.title: Brazil’s Far-Right Disinformation Pushers Find a Safe Space on Telegram
item.description: In a social media ecosystem facing mounting pressure to combat fake news and polarization, Telegram is the most permissive disseminator of content — and disinformation.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño, Flávia Milhorance and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Jair Bolsonaro at a rally. Ahead of next year’s presidential elections, Mr. Bolsonaro urged his voters to follow him on Telegram.

item.title: Thousands of Canadians Head for the Southern United States Again
item.description: With the border opening to tourists, thousands of Canadian “snowbirds” are on their way to Florida, Arizona and California with campers in tow.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: The swimming pool area at the Country Roads RV Village in Yuma, Ariz.

item.title: Northern Ireland’s Health Minister Is Suing Van Morrison Over Covid Criticism
item.description: The Belfast-born singer-songwriter has embraced conspiracy theories and criticized restrictions to slow the spread of the coronavirus. Last year, he released a single called “No More Lockdown.”
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Van Morrison performing in London in 2020. He has been an outspoken critic of pandemic safety protocols.

item.title: Despite Abuses of NSO Spyware, Israel Will Lobby U.S. to Defend It
item.description: As a new accusation surfaces that NSO’s software may have been used to spy on Palestinians, Israeli officials say it is crucial to national security.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A branch of the Israeli NSO Group company, near the southern Israeli town of Sapir.

item.title: Excited Passengers Board First Flight from Heathrow to the U.S.
item.description: Long lines formed at Heathrow Airport for the first scheduled trips to the United States since the Biden administration lifted a travel ban.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu
item.media:credit: Alex Ingram for The New York Times
item.media:description: Performers hired by Virgin Atlantic welcomed U.S.-bound travelers on Monday at Heathrow Airport, near London.

item.title: U.S. Covid Deaths Get Even Redder
item.description: The partisan gap in Covid’s death toll has grown faster over the past month than at any previous point.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A nurse in Rexburg, Idaho monitors a covid patient.

item.title: In hard-hit Romania, the virus is surging as vaccine hesitancy spreads.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: A banner reading, “No to vaccination — our children are not your guinea pigs,” at a protest in Bucharest, Romania, on Sunday.

item.title: New Zealand's Biggest City Is to Ease Lockdown Restrictions
item.description: The lifting of rules comes as the country records some of its highest daily case numbers since the pandemic began.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A rally outside the Auckland War Memorial Museum in October to protest lockdowns in New Zealand.

item.title: Inside a Volcanic Ritual on the Indonesian Island of Java
item.description: During the Hindu ceremony of Yadnya Kasada, the Tenggerese people toss offerings — food, money, flowers, livestock — into the hazy crater of Mount Bromo.
item.dc:creator: Putu Sayoga
item.media:description: A view of Mount Batok, as seen from Mount Bromo, during the Hindu ritual of Yadnya Kasada.

item.title: When the Taliban Are in Your Bedroom
item.description: As armed Taliban inspected the New York Times bureau in Kabul, they were escorted by a journalist who used to be a U.S. Marine. The photo of him in uniform was plain for all to see, and ponder.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Body armor sits in the New York Times bureau in Kabul, Afghanistan.

item.title: Police Officer Stabbed on French Riviera, Authorities Say
item.description: Gérald Darmanin, France’s interior minister, said an assailant had stabbed an officer in Cannes. The motive for the attack was not immediately clear.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Éric Ciotti, a lawmaker who represents the Alpes-Maritimes area, visiting the police station in Cannes where a police officer was reported stabbed on Monday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Rewriting China’s past.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: People in Shanghai watched Xi Jinping speak on Thursday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: China’s new official history.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: People in Shanghai watched a broadcast of China’s President Xi Jinping speaking on Thursday.

item.title: Afghan Military Pilots, on the Run, Feel Abandoned by U.S.
item.description: Detained in Tajikistan, or hiding from the Taliban in Afghanistan, many pilots wonder why the military that trained them is not coming to their aid.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Afghan Air Force training exercise in Logar Province in 2018. The United States spent billions of dollars training and equipping Afghan forces.
